intro: Racosperma chalkeri, commonly known as the Chalky Hill Senna, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are bipinnate, and it produces yellow flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and birds. Racosperma chalkeri is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its hardy nature and ability to stabilize soil.
